title: 114_hr920
content: The "Smarter Sentencing Act of 2015" clarifies the applicability of statutory minimums and the Fair Sentencing Act. It amends Section 3553(f)(1) of title 18, United States Code, to specify that the criminal history category for the defendant must not be higher than category 2. The term "covered offense" refers to a violation of a Federal criminal statute with penalties modified by the Fair Sentencing Act of 2010 before August 3, 2010. Courts can reduce sentences for covered offenses if requested by the defendant, Director of the Bureau of Prisons, attorney for the Government, or the court. No motion to reduce a sentence can be entertained if the sentence was previously imposed or reduced in accordance with the Act. The Fair Sentencing Act of 2010 allows for the reduction of sentences for certain offenses, but courts are not required to do so. The Fair Sentencing Act of 2010 allows for sentencing modifications for certain drug offenses. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to define a "courier" and modify sentencing guidelines for drug offenses, reducing the minimum sentence to 5 years and 10 years for certain offenses. The Controlled Substances Import and Export Act is amended to reduce the minimum sentence for certain drug offenses to 5 years and 10 years. The Controlled Substances Import and Export Act is amended to reduce the minimum sentence for certain drug offenses to 5 years and 10 years. In paragraph (1), the text is amended to include harsher penalties for couriers committing drug offenses. The Controlled Substances Import and Export Act is amended to impose harsher penalties for couriers committing drug offenses, including a minimum sentence of 2 years to life for a first offense and 5 years to life for repeat offenses. The Controlled Substances Import and Export Act is amended to impose harsher penalties for drug offenses, with a minimum sentence of 5 years to life for repeat offenses. Directive to the Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend its guidelines for individuals convicted of drug offenses to decrease penalties in accordance with recent amendments. The Commission must consider its mandate under the law while making these changes. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to formulate sentencing guidelines to minimize federal prison overcrowding, considering findings on mandatory minimum penalties, fiscal implications, public safety concerns, and penalties for violent drug traffickers. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to formulate guidelines to reduce racial disparities in federal sentencing and address public safety risks posed by serious drug traffickers. The Commission must act promptly to implement the guidelines outlined in the Act. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to formulate guidelines to reduce racial disparities in federal sentencing and address public safety risks posed by serious drug traffickers. The Commission may adjust sentencing guidelines as necessary to achieve consistency with other provisions and applicable law. The Attorney General must submit a report within 6 months of the Act's enactment detailing how reduced expenditures on Federal corrections will be used to reduce prison overcrowding, increase investment in law enforcement and crime prevention, and decrease criminal recidivism. Additionally, a report on Federal criminal offenses is required. The Attorney General is required to submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment, listing all criminal statutory offenses and their potential penalties. The report required by the Act includes a list of criminal regulatory offenses enforceable by Federal agencies and the mens rea requirement for each offense. The Act requires a report listing criminal regulatory offenses, their potential penalties, number of violations referred for prosecution, and mens rea requirements. Federal agencies involved include Agriculture, Commerce, and Education. The Act requires a report listing criminal regulatory offenses, their potential penalties, number of violations referred for prosecution, and mens rea requirements. Federal agencies involved include Department of Commerce, Department of Education, Department of Energy, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Homeland Security, Department of Housing and Urban Development, Department of the Interior, Department of Labor, Department of Transportation, Department of the Treasury, Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Consumer Product Safety Commission, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Export-Import Bank of the United States, Farm Credit Administration, Federal Communications Commission, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Federal Election Commission, Federal Labor Relations Authority, Federal Maritime Commission, Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission, Federal Trade Commission, National Labor. The Act requires a report listing criminal regulatory offenses from various federal agencies, including the Department of Commerce, Department of Education, Department of Energy, and others. The Attorney General will establish a publicly accessible index of these offenses within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Act mandates the establishment of a publicly accessible index of criminal regulatory offenses by federal agencies, including the Department of Justice. No appropriations are required or authorized for this purpose.
